Please join me in taking a moment to honor the lives and work of Harriet Tubman, Frederick Douglass, and everyone who fought to make our country a better place. #NY24 and the surrounding region have such an important history to recognize and celebrate. #BlackHistoryMonth

Douglass worked closely with suffragette Susan B. Anthony, fighting for abolition and women's rights. He often visited Seneca Falls to support Anthony's efforts and was laid to rest beside her in Rochester.

Frederick Douglass, another one of the most admired civil rights leaders in American History, lived most of his life in Rochester NY, where he published his historic "North Star" newspaper, assisted with the underground railroad, and even hosted runaway slaves at his home.

Harriet lived in Auburn from 1859 to 1913 while rescuing over 70 slaves on 13 trips to the enslaved South.

Her relentless commitment to liberty and justice for all has earned her a spot as one of the most revered freedom fighters in American History.

I had the privilege of touring the historic home of Harriet Tubman in Auburn and honoring the life and work of a true hero who fought every day for a better America. She is an inspiration to me and so many Americans of different races, creeds, and religions.
In honor of #BlackHistoryMonth, we wanted to highlight the amazing and inspirational history #NY24 and New York State played in advancing the cause of liberty for all.

RT @HouseGOP House Republicans are taking action to protect our economy, rein in inflationary spending, and put American families first.

The global competition between dictatorship and democracy is center stage in Ukraine. The world is watching to see whether we have the courage of our convictions. America will not shrink from supporting freedom.
The courage and determination of Ukraine‚Äôs soldiers, leaders, and citizens has far exceeded expectations. The war is theirs to fight; we aid them with weapons and funds.

We must make clear with our actions in Ukraine that we‚Äôll help people defend themselves. 40% of U.S. aid for Ukraine is used to buy American-made weapons & improve U.S. readiness. The cost of our support is significant but fortunately, there‚Äôs no blood being shed by our soldiers.

How we respond to Russia‚Äôs invasion is watched closely by China as it eyes invading Taiwan. It's in our interests to safeguard freedom and stop China from having free rein over its neighbor. Taiwan also produces almost 3/4 of the semiconductors we need for our economy & military.

We stand with our allies: the EU reports that its members have contributed $74 billion to Ukraine. Its people are suffering from soaring energy prices because Russia has shut gas lines. Yet our friends have taken in millions of Ukrainian refugees.

In 1994, as an inducement for Ukraine to relinquish its nuclear weapons, America made security assurances regarding Ukraine‚Äôs sovereignty‚Äîand we will honor those assurances. A nation perceived as abandoning its commitments will have few allies when they are needed.
Russia‚Äôs invasion of Ukraine has devastated Russia‚Äôs military, weakening an adversary. That‚Äôs a good thing! And its underwhelming military performance has diminished its global standing.
An emboldened and expansionist Russia may eventually invade one of our NATO allies, drawing America into war.

It is in America‚Äôs interest to support Ukraine. If Russia can invade, subjugate, and pillage Ukraine with impunity, it will do the same again to others, and a world at war diminishes the security of Americans.
